docs.lead_paragraph: He is called Japan's Don Quixote, and indeed, it does seem that Junichiro Koizumi is tilting at windmills. Or, rather, tilting at post offices -- 24,667 of them, to be exact. Mr. Koizumi, Minister of Health and Welfare, wants to privatize them, contending that no less than Japan's future role as a world financial leader hangs in the balance.

headline.main: Crusader Takes On the Postal Piggy Bank

docs.abstract: Japan's Minister of Health and Welfare Junichiro Koizumi is pushing measures that would have post offices and banks compete more equally in financial services to dismay of many Japanese and their postmasters; Koizumi wants to privatize nation's 24,667 post offices, contending that no less than Japan's future role as world financial leader hangs in the balance; Japan's post office is also financial monolith, taking care of some $2 trillion in savings and $800 billion in life insurance policies; Koizumi says postal system is juggernaut threatening to strangle Japan's private financial institutions; privatizing postal system is seen as litmus test of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's resolve to reduce Government influence and unlease market forces on Japan's economy; graph; chart; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Soccer moms, people who drive school carpools and others who can state that they drive more children than will fit in back seats will be permitted to have switches installed to disable passenger-side airbags, as part of a new Federal policy to be announced on Tuesday. The rule, to be issued by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, marks a conspicuous U-turn on airbags, devices required by law in new cars on the driver's side in the steering column and on the passenger's side. The new rule not only will allow car owners to have mechanics install switches to disable passenger-side air bags, but in some cases will also allow owners to get permission to have the driver's side bags disconnected.

headline.main: CUTOFF SWITCHES FOR CAR AIRBAGS WILL BE ALLOWED

docs.abstract: New Federal policy will allow drivers to install switches to disable passenger-side airbags, and in some cases, to have driver's side bags disconnected; even though transportation officials assert airbags remain life-saving devices for majority of people, their design has proved dangerous to small children and petite women as use of passenger-side bags has widened; standard bags can expand at up to 200 miles per hour in crash, or fast enough to cushion average-sized man not wearing seatbelt at 30 miles-per-hour, but their inflation is so fast that they have killed 87 people, including 49 children, over past 10 years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN 1971, James Reston, The New York Times columnist, introduced the Western world to the ancient Chinese therapy of acupuncture. Mr. Reston, who underwent an emergency appendectomy in China, described acupuncture's success in relieving his postoperative pain. Since then, acupuncture has flourished in the West, mainly among lay practitioners trained in this technique, in which certain points are stimulated on or under the skin, mostly with ultrafine needles. Several thousand doctors in this country have also been trained and now use acupuncture in their medical practices.

headline.main: Personal Health; Acupuncture: An Expensive Placebo or a Legitimate Alternative?

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on acupuncture and whether it is an expensive placebo or a legitimate alternative to other therapies, especially with regard to chronic pain; notes acupuncture is flourishing in West, mainly among lay practitioners; suggests guidelines for choosing an acupuncturist; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MISCONCEPTIONS about acupuncture abound. While some believe that it is a highly effective pain reliever, others say it is nothing more than a glorified and expensive placebo lacking scientific proof for the many claims made in its behalf. The truth, according to nearly a score of reports made to a Federally sponsored conference this month, lies somewhere in between. Acupuncture researchers from the this country and abroad were invited by the National Institutes of Health to summarize the best available evidence, pro and con, for the effectiveness of acupuncture in their fields. Their reports, which examined topics ranging from acupuncture's well-publicized ability to relieve pain to its potential effects on respiration, digestion, immunity and even fertility, more than anything begged for longer, larger and better controlled studies to document carefully what acupuncture can and cannot do.

headline.main: Weighing Pros and Cons While the Jury Is Out

docs.abstract: Federally appointed panel clears up some misconceptions about acupuncture, weighing its effectiveness in pain control, addiction, pulmonary disease, immune functions and nausea; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two large health organizations announced a new business yesterday that they said would streamline the process of checking doctors' credentials. G.N.Y.H.A. Ventures, a subsidiary of the Greater New York Hospital Association, and M.S.S.N.Y.-M.L.M.I.C. Management services, a company owned jointly by the Medical Society of the State of New York and the Medical Liability Mutual Insurance Company, said the business would provide credential references that would be accepted by hospitals and the growing number of managed-care providers, relieving doctors of the need to apply for credentials repeatedly.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation is expected as early as today to announce a broad reorganization that would cut its giant network of almost 350 hospitals by at least a third and reduce the number of its administrators. Under the plan, people with ties to the company said yesterday, Columbia would move more than 100 hospitals out of the company. Under the leading option being considered, the hospitals would be placed in a separate corporate unit that would either be sold outright or spun off to Columbia shareholders through a distribution of stock.

headline.main: Columbia/HCA Planning to Cut Network by at Least a Third

docs.lead_paragraph: SUMMONED for an announcement by Bishop John R. McGann of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, 125 board members of the four Catholic hospitals on Long Island assembled in his rectory on a Friday evening last month. Few among the current and former corporate leaders, Wall Street executives, top administrators, business owners, judges, lawyers, doctors and members of the clergy, a virtual Who's Who of community leaders and fund-raisers, guessed that they were facing a mass dismissal.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the legal world, Melvyn Weiss is perhaps best known as the ''dean of the plaintiff's bar,'' and with good reason: a senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach LLP, he has been a pioneer in the field of class-action law. Throughout his 30-year career, he won victories for plaintiffs in such landmark cases as the Drexel/Milken litigations, where he recovered nearly $1 billion for investors in Columbia Savings and Loan; the Washington Public Power Supply Systems Securities litigations, where he was one of three court-appointed lead counsels who recovered $775 million; Newman v. Stringfellow, in which he successfully represented 4,000 people exposed to toxic pollutants in Southern California and the much-publicized Exxon Valdez case.
